title: Why you procrastinate even when it feels bad

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between responsible time management and procrastination?

options.label: A
options.text: Responsible time management requires deciding which tasks are urgent, while procrastination involves putting off tasks that are not urgent.

options.label: B
options.text: Procrastination is when we avoid a task we said we would do, for no good reason, despite expecting our behavior to bring negative consequences.

options.label: C
options.text: Procrastination is when we put off tasks that are important, while responsible time management involves prioritizing tasks that are not important.

options.label: D
options.text: Procrastination is when we put off tasks that are easy, while responsible time management involves prioritizing tasks that are difficult.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the amygdala in the process of procrastination?

options.label: A
options.text: The amygdala helps to regulate emotions and reduce stress.

options.label: B
options.text: The amygdala releases hormones that kick off a fear response, making it difficult to start a task.

options.label: C
options.text: The amygdala is responsible for decision-making and problem-solving.

options.label: D
options.text: The amygdala has no role in the process of procrastination.

multiple-choice.question: What is a common misconception about procrastinators?

options.label: A
options.text: That all procrastinators are highly motivated and organized.

options.label: B
options.text: That all procrastinators are lazy and lack discipline.

options.label: C
options.text: That procrastinators are only motivated by a desire to avoid work.

options.label: D
options.text: That procrastinators are only motivated by a desire to succeed.

multiple-choice.question: What is a strategy for breaking the cycle of procrastination?

options.label: A
options.text: Breaking a task into smaller elements or journaling about why it's stressing you out and addressing those underlying concerns.

options.label: B
options.text: Removing nearby distractions that make it easy to impulsively procrastinate.

options.label: C
options.text: Cultivating an attitude of self-compassion, forgiving yourself, and making a plan to do better next time.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What are some negative consequences of procrastination?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased productivity and motivation.

options.label: B
options.text: Reduced stress levels and improved physical health.

options.label: C
options.text: Frequent procrastinators are likely to suffer from anxiety and depression, ongoing feelings of shame, higher stress levels, and physical ailments associated with high stress.

options.label: D
options.text: Procrastination has no negative consequences.

title: A brie(f) history of cheese - Paul S. Kindstedt

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, when did the earliest Neolithic farmers in the Fertile Crescent begin a legacy of cheesemaking?

options.label: A
options.text: 5000 BCE

options.label: B
options.text: 6000 BCE

options.label: C
options.text: 8000 BCE

options.label: D
options.text: 9000 BCE

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary advantage of cheese over milk for ancient people?

options.label: A
options.text: Cheese contained more lactose than milk.

options.label: B
options.text: Cheese was easier to digest than milk.

options.label: C
options.text: Cheese provided essential proteins, fats, and minerals with much less lactose than milk.

options.label: D
options.text: Cheese was a more expensive food than milk.

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of rennet in cheesemaking?

options.label: A
options.text: It was a type of cheese that could be produced with rennet.

options.label: B
options.text: It was an animal byproduct that could accelerate and control coagulation.

options.label: C
options.text: It was a type of milk that could be used to produce cheese.

options.label: D
options.text: It was a type of tool used to age cheese.

multiple-choice.question: What type of cheese was produced in Sicily and used in dishes across the Mediterranean?

options.label: A
options.text: Feta cheese

options.label: B
options.text: Pecorino Romano cheese

options.label: C
options.text: Grating cheese

options.label: D
options.text: Dry cheese

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary factor that led to the evolution of cheesemaking in the medieval European countryside?

options.label: A
options.text: The collapse of the Western Roman Empire

options.label: B
options.text: The rise of the Roman Empire

options.label: C
options.text: The development of new technologies

options.label: D
options.text: The experimentation of medieval monks with different types of milk, cheesemaking practices, and aging processes.

title: The last chief of the Comanches and the fall of an empire - Dustin Tahmahkera

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the young chief who led the Comanche raid on a sleeping army camp in 1871?

options.label: A
options.text: Quanah Parker

options.label: B
options.text: Ranald MacKenzie

options.label: C
options.text: Peta Nocona

options.label: D
options.text: Naduah

multiple-choice.question: What was the main reason for the conflict between the Comanches and the United States forces?

options.label: A
options.text: The Comanches wanted to steal land from the United States.

options.label: B
options.text: The United States forces wanted to steal Comanche lands for white settlers.

options.label: C
options.text: The Comanches and the United States forces were competing for buffalo hides.

options.label: D
options.text: The Comanches and the United States forces were fighting over resources.

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of Quanah's mother, who was a kidnapped white settler who assimilated with the Comanches?

options.label: A
options.text: Cynthia Ann Parker

options.label: B
options.text: Naduah

options.label: C
options.text: Weakeah

options.label: D
options.text: Quanah's mother was not mentioned by name.

multiple-choice.question: Why did Quanah and the Quahada band move to the Fort Sill reservation in Oklahoma?

options.label: A
options.text: They were forced to move by the U.S. government.

options.label: B
options.text: They wanted to transition to an agricultural way of life.

options.label: C
options.text: They had no horses or buffalo, and were facing starvation.

options.label: D
options.text: They were looking for a new source of income.

multiple-choice.question: What was Quanah's role in the Comanche Nation after his passing?

options.label: A
options.text: He was remembered as a great warrior.

options.label: B
options.text: He was recognized as the last chief of the Comanches and a model of cultural survival and adaptation.

options.label: C
options.text: He was forgotten by the Comanche Nation.

options.label: D
options.text: He was replaced by a new chief.

title: History through the eyes of the potato - Leo Bear-McGuinness

multiple-choice.question: Where did the ancient Peruvians first cultivate the potato?

options.label: A
options.text: In the Rocky Mountains

options.label: B
options.text: High atop the Andes

options.label: C
options.text: In the fertile plains of South America

options.label: D
options.text: In the dense forests of Europe

multiple-choice.question: Why did Europeans initially reject the potato as a food source?

options.label: A
options.text: They found it to be too expensive

options.label: B
options.text: They considered it a delicacy

options.label: C
options.text: They thought it was dull and tasteless, and too closely related to the deadly nightshade plant belladonna

options.label: D
options.text: They believed it was a staple food of the Incan Empire

multiple-choice.question: What was the effect of the Irish adopting the potato as a major food staple?

options.label: A
options.text: Their population decreased due to lack of food

options.label: B
options.text: Their dependence on the tuber increased, leading to a dramatic increase in population

options.label: C
options.text: They became less dependent on the potato and more on grains

options.label: D
options.text: They stopped eating potatoes altogether

multiple-choice.question: What was the devastating effect of potato blight disease on Ireland's potato crop?

options.label: A
options.text: It led to a slight decrease in population

options.label: B
options.text: It caused a moderate increase in poverty

options.label: C
options.text: It ravaged the majority of Ireland's potato crop, leading to the Irish Potato Famine, one of the deadliest famines in world history

options.label: D
options.text: It had no significant impact on Ireland's population

multiple-choice.question: What was the long-term effect of the potato on European society?

options.label: A
options.text: It led to a decrease in the working class population

options.label: B
options.text: It caused a shift away from industrialization

options.label: C
options.text: It contributed to the growth of European empires and the emergence of the modern world via the Industrial Revolution

options.label: D
options.text: It had no significant impact on European society

title: The best way to apologize (according to science)

multiple-choice.question: What is the centerpiece of an apology?

options.label: A
options.text: The offer of repair

options.label: B
options.text: Taking the victim's perspective

options.label: C
options.text: Understanding and accepting responsibility for your actions

options.label: D
options.text: Clarifying your intentions non-defensively

multiple-choice.question: Why is a good apology not about making you feel better?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it's too difficult to feel better

options.label: B
options.text: Because it's not about you, but about the other person

options.label: C
options.text: Because it's too expensive to make you feel better

options.label: D
options.text: Because it's not a priority

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of an offer of repair?

options.label: A
options.text: A verbal commitment not to make the same mistake again

options.label: B
options.text: A symbolic expression of love and respect

options.label: C
options.text: Replacing the ice cream you ate

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What is the goal of an apology?

options.label: A
options.text: To get forgiveness and move on

options.label: B
options.text: To express remorse and accept accountability

options.label: C
options.text: To make the other person feel better

options.label: D
options.text: To defend your actions

multiple-choice.question: Why is it helpful to ask the person you've wronged how they feel?

options.label: A
options.text: So you can rationalize your actions

options.label: B
options.text: So you can understand their perspective and take responsibility for your actions

options.label: C
options.text: So you can avoid apologizing

options.label: D
options.text: So you can make excuses

title: Does working hard really make you a good person? - Azim Shariff

multiple-choice.question: In the hypothetical scenario presented by the researcher, what was the reaction of the participants when they heard about Jeff, the medical scribe who chose to keep working despite the software doing his job?

options.label: A
options.text: They saw him as more competent but less moral.

options.label: B
options.text: They saw him as less competent but more moral.

options.label: C
options.text: They saw him as equally competent and moral.

options.label: D
options.text: They saw him as neither competent nor moral.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the system that, alongside capitalism, creates a culture where people are forced to participate in the expectation of being a hard worker?

options.label: A
options.text: Workism

options.label: B
options.text: Capitalism

options.label: C
options.text: Protestant work ethic

options.label: D
options.text: Partner choice

multiple-choice.question: According to the researcher, what is the problem with the culture that asks for the wrong thing, where people are rewarded for their effort rather than their productivity?

options.label: A
options.text: It creates a world of lazy people.

options.label: B
options.text: It creates a world of hard labor and cobras.

options.label: C
options.text: It creates a world of meaningless work.

options.label: D
options.text: It creates a world of people who are not motivated.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the bias that connects effort to morality, making people see hard work as a moral quality?

options.label: A
options.text: Effort moralization

options.label: B
options.text: Partner choice

options.label: C
options.text: Workism

options.label: D
options.text: Protestant work ethic

multiple-choice.question: What is the consequence of a culture that asks for the wrong thing, where people are rewarded for their effort rather than their productivity?

options.label: A
options.text: It creates a world of people who are not motivated.

options.label: B
options.text: It creates a world of lazy people.

options.label: C
options.text: It creates a world of meaningless work.

options.label: D
options.text: It creates a world of hard labor and cobras.

title: Why it’s so hard to make healthy decisions - David Asch

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the main weakness in our approach to improving health behavior?

options.label: A
options.text: We don't provide enough education to patients.

options.label: B
options.text: We assume people behave rationally and make decisions based on information.

options.label: C
options.text: We don't use enough technology to monitor patient behavior.

options.label: D
options.text: We don't have enough resources to fund health care programs.

multiple-choice.question: What is "present bias," and how does it affect our behavior?

options.label: A
options.text: Present bias is when we prioritize short-term gains over long-term benefits.

options.label: B
options.text: Present bias is when we prioritize long-term benefits over short-term gains.

options.label: C
options.text: Present bias is when we don't consider the consequences of our actions.

options.label: D
options.text: Present bias is when we only consider our own interests.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between a gain-framed incentive and a loss-framed incentive?

options.label: A
options.text: A gain-framed incentive is more expensive than a loss-framed incentive.

options.label: B
options.text: A gain-framed incentive is less effective than a loss-framed incentive.

options.label: C
options.text: A gain-framed incentive offers a reward for achieving a goal, while a loss-framed incentive offers a penalty for not achieving a goal.

options.label: D
options.text: A gain-framed incentive is only available to certain individuals.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of making financial incentives in health care too expensive or too cheap?

options.label: A
options.text: Financial incentives become more effective when they are expensive.

options.label: B
options.text: Financial incentives become more effective when they are cheap.

options.label: C
options.text: Financial incentives become less effective when they are too expensive or too cheap.

options.label: D
options.text: Financial incentives have no effect on health behavior.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of how social influence can be used to improve health behavior?

options.label: A
options.text: A hospital installing a fine for late pickups.

options.label: B
options.text: A daycare program installing a fine for late pickups.

options.label: C
options.text: A doctor using antibiotics more appropriately when they see how other doctors use them.

options.label: D
options.text: A patient taking their medication because they are being rewarded with a lottery.

title: Should you care what your parents think?

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the motivational state that occurs when people feel their freedom is being threatened?

options.label: A
options.text: Reactance theory

options.label: B
options.text: Social Network Effect

options.label: C
options.text: Defiant reactance

options.label: D
options.text: Independent reactance

options.label: A
options.text: A steady increase in love for one another

options.label: B
options.text: A decrease in love for one another

options.label: C
options.text: No significant change in love for one another

options.label: D
options.text: The couples reported a steady increase in arguments

options.label: A
options.text: Reactance theory

options.label: B
options.text: Social Network Effect

options.label: C
options.text: Defiant reactance

options.label: D
options.text: Independent reactance

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what are the two types of reactance?

options.label: A
options.text: Defiant reactance and Social Network Effect

options.label: B
options.text: Defiant reactance and independent reactance

options.label: C
options.text: Social Network Effect and independent reactance

options.label: D
options.text: Defiant reactance and internalized reactance

multiple-choice.question: What is the outcome of having a supportive social network in a romantic relationship?

options.label: A
options.text: The relationship is more likely to fail

options.label: B
options.text: The relationship is less likely to succeed

options.label: C
options.text: The relationship can endure disapproval from others

options.label: D

title: How do carbohydrates impact your health? - Richard J. Wood

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following has the least carbohydrates?

options.label: A
options.text: This roll of bread

options.label: B
options.text: This bowl of rice

options.label: C
options.text: This can of soda

options.label: D
options.text: They are all similar in carbs

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between starches and fiber in terms of how they affect the body?

options.label: A
options.text: Starches are broken down quickly, while fiber is broken down slowly.

options.label: B
options.text: Starches are broken down slowly, while fiber is broken down quickly.

options.label: C
options.text: Starches are composed of alpha linkages, while fiber is composed of beta linkages.

options.label: D
options.text: Fiber is composed of alpha linkages, while starches are composed of beta linkages.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the amount that a particular food raises the sugar level in your blood?

options.label: A
options.text: Glycemic index

options.label: B
options.text: Insulin sensitivity

options.label: C
options.text: Insulin resistance

options.label: D
options.text: Metabolic syndrome

multiple-choice.question: What hormone is secreted into the blood when blood sugar rises, prompting muscle and fat cells to let glucose in?

options.label: A
options.text: Glucagon

options.label: B
options.text: Insulin

options.label: C
options.text: Adrenaline

options.label: D
options.text: Thyroid hormone

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the condition where the pancreas still sends out insulin, but cells are less responsive to it, leading to high blood sugar and other symptoms?

options.label: A
options.text: Insulin resistance

options.label: B
options.text: Insulin sensitivity

options.label: C
options.text: Metabolic syndrome

options.label: D
options.text: Glycemic index

title: How the food you eat affects your gut - Shilpa Ravella

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the gut microbiome?

options.label: A
options.text: To break down food the body can't digest and produce important nutrients.

options.label: B
options.text: To regulate the immune system and protect against harmful germs.

options.label: C
options.text: To aid in the digestion of high-fat and high-sugar foods.

options.label: D
options.text: To increase the production of toxins in the body.

multiple-choice.question: What is the best fuel for gut bacteria?

options.label: A
options.text: High-fat and high-sugar foods.

options.label: B
options.text: Fiber from foods like fruits, vegetables, nuts, legumes, and whole grains.

options.label: C
options.text: Processed meats and dairy products.

options.label: D
options.text: Sugary drinks and refined carbohydrates.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the gut bacteria when we eat low-fiber processed foods?

options.label: A
options.text: They become more diverse and healthy.

options.label: B
options.text: They die off due to lack of fuel.

options.label: C
options.text: They start to feed on the mucus lining.

options.label: D
options.text: They become less hungry and more efficient.

multiple-choice.question: Which foods are correlated with increased bacterial diversity?

options.label: A
options.text: Fruits, vegetables, tea, coffee, red wine, and dark chocolate.

options.label: B
options.text: Processed meats, dairy products, and sugary drinks.

options.label: C
options.text: Fermented foods like kimchi and sauerkraut.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What is one way to introduce good bacteria, also known as probiotics, into your gut?

options.label: A
options.text: By eating fermented foods like kimchi and sauerkraut.

options.label: B
options.text: By drinking sugary drinks and refined carbohydrates.

options.label: C
options.text: By taking antibiotics and other medications.

options.label: D
options.text: By eating processed meats and dairy products.
